qas.question: In what year did Thomas J. Watson, Sr. join CTR?
Thomas J. Watson Sr. was fired from what company?
What was the favorite slogan of Thomas J. Watson Sr.?
The revenues did what under the first 4 years of Watson being president?
The name International Business Machines was first used in what year?
In what year did CTR first use THINK as its slogan?
Who did Thomas J. Watson, Sr fire from the CTR company?
When did Patterson join the National Cash Register Company?

plausible_answers.text: revenues more than doubled to $9 million

qas.question: What happened to the revenue of the National Cash Register Company when Patterson became president?

plausible_answers.text: generous sales incentives, a focus on customer service

qas.question: What kind of benefits were given to employees of the National Cash Register Company?

context: Thomas J. Watson, Sr., fired from the <a1_0>National Cash Register Company<a1_0/> by <b6_0>John Henry Patterson<b6_0/>, called on Flint and, <b5_0>in <a0_0><b7_0>1914<b7_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>, was offered CTR. Watson joined CTR as General Manager then, 11 months later, was made President when court cases relating to his time at NCR were resolved. Having learned Patterson's pioneering business practices, Watson proceeded to put the stamp of NCR onto CTR's companies. He implemented sales conventions, "<b9_0>generous sales incentives, a focus on customer service<b9_0/>, an insistence on well-groomed, dark-suited salesmen and had an evangelical fervor for instilling company pride and loyalty in every worker". His favorite slogan, "<a2_0>THINK<a2_0/>", became a mantra for each company's employees. During Watson's first four years, <b8_0>revenues <a3_0>more than doubled to $9 million<b8_0/><a3_0/> and the company's operations expanded to Europe, South America, Asia and Australia. "Watson had never liked the clumsy hyphenated title of the CTR" and chose to replace it with the more expansive title "International Business Machines". First as a name for a <a4_0>1917<a4_0/> Canadian subsidiary, then as a line in advertisements. For example, the McClures magazine, v53, May 1921, has a full page ad with, at the bottom:
